$DATUM Synthesis of V(N-2,6-Me2C6H3)(CHDSiMe3)(C6D5)(ImDIPPN) (3-d6). A C6D6
solution (ca. 2 mL) containing the dialkyl complex 2 (80 mg, 0.107 mmol)
was heated at 60 °C in a sealed tube under a nitrogen atmosphere. After 4
days, the solvent was then removed in vacuo and the resulting residue was
extracted with n-hexane. The solution was then placed in vacuo, and the
resultant tan residue was dissolved in the minimum amount of n-hexane
(about 0.3 mL). The chilled solution (-30 °C) gave red microcrystals, 66
mg, 0.088 mmol, yield of 82%. 1H NMR (C6D6): δ 7.26 (t, 2H, J = 7.60,
Ar-H), 7.07 (t, 4H, J = 7.60, Ar-H), 6.97 (d, 2H, J = 7.60, Ar-H), 6.80
(t, 1H, J = 7.60, Ar-H), 5.82 (s, 2H, CH=), 3.05 (m, 2H, CH(CH3)2), 2.93
(m, 2H, CH(CH3)2), 2.37 (s, 6H, ArCH3), 1.23 (d, 6H, J = 6.80, CH(CH3)2),
1.17 (d, 6H, J = 7.20, CH(CH3)2), 1.09 (d, 6H, J = 7.20, CH(CH3)2), 1.05
(d, 6H, J = 7.20, CH(CH3)2),-0.02 (s, 9H, CH2SiH3). 13C NMR (C6D6): δ
147.0, 146.9, 133.5, 130.3, 128.3, 127.3, 124.5, 124.4, 122.4, 115.5,
29.2, 29.1, 24.4, 24.0, 23.5, 23.0, 20.3, 2.3. 51V NMR (C6D6): δ 294
(Δν1/2 = 756 Hz). Anal. Calcd for C45H55D6N4SiV: C, 72.74; H, 8.29; N,
7.54. Found: C, 72.63; H, 8.29; N, 7.47.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM NMR-Scale Reaction of α-Chloronorbornene with Cp*TiMe3/Ph3C+B(C6F5)4-. In
the glovebox, a J. Young NMR tube was chargedwith Cp*TiMe3 (3.0 mg, 0.013
mmol), Ph3C+B(C6F5)4- (12.1 mg, 0.013mmol), and benzene-d6 (0.60 mL). The
tube was sealed and vigorouslyagitated for 2 min at room temperature, and
then 10.0 equiv of α-chloronorbornene (20.0 μL) was added. An immediate
dark-redsolution was obtained. A 1H NMR spectrum recorded in less than 5
minrevealed complete consumption of α-chloronorbornene (as evidencedby
the disappearance of the olefinic proton resonance at δ 5.58) andafforded
exo-1-chloro-2-phenyl-d5-norbornane-7-d1 (1a-d6)
quantitatively.Similarly, the activation reaction of Cp*TiMe3 with 0.92
equivof Ph3C+B(C6F5)4- in benzene-d6 (0.6 mL), followed by addition
of10.0 equiv of R-chloronorbornene at room temperature, leads to
thequantitative formation of 1a-d6 in less than 5 min, yield 100%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM regioselective
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Frustrated β-Chloride Elimination. Selective Arene Alkylation by
α-Chloronorbornene Catalyzed by Electrophilic Metallocenium Ion Pairs
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Dash, Aswini K.; Jensen, Tryg R.; Stern, Charlotte L.; Marks, Tobin J.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of the American Chemical Society (2004), 126(39), 12528-12540

$DATUM [(C5Me5)2U]2(μ-η6:η6-C6D6), 1-d6, from 1. A solution of
[(C5Me5)2U]2(μ-η6:η6-C6H6) (10 g, 0.009 mmol) in C6D6 in an NMR tube
sealed under vacuum was heated at 65 °C and monitored daily by 1H NMR
spectroscopy. After 7 days, quantitative conversion from 1 to 1-d6 had
occurred. [(C5Me5)2U]2(μ-η6:η6-C6D6), 1-d6, quantitative yield 1H NMR

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Immediately upon isolation, the brown solid was dissolved in C6D6 and
transferred to an NMR tube. The tube was sealed under vacuum and heated
to 65 °C. The reaction was monitored by 1H NMR spectroscopy, and
quantitative conversion to 1-d6 occurred within 12 h (see above).
[(C5Me5)2U]2(μ-η6:η6-C6D6), 1-d6, quantitative yield 1H NMR (C6D6, 298
K): δ 3.02 (s, H-C5Me5, 1JC,H 125, ∆ν1/2 6 Hz). 2H NMR (C6H5Me, 2.09):
-98.3 (s, D-C6D6, ∆ν1/2 29 Hz).

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: In a typical experiment, the host TP2 (50.0
mg, 0.07 mmol) was dissolved in 20 mL of ethyl acetate/methanol, and a
few drops of guests was introduced without causing precipitation. The
resultant solution was allowed to evaporate over a period of 7-10 days to
yield colorless crystals quantitatively. The crystals were characterized
by 1H NMR, TGA, and X-ray crystallography. A similar procedure was used
for the synthesis of inclusion compounds of BX. TP2·nitrobenzene·benzene;
(TP2=1,3,6,8-Tetrakis(2,6-dimethyl-4-hydroxyphenyl)pyrene). Formula:
C66H59NO6; FW: 962.18; Crystal system: Monoclinic; SG: P21; a(Å ):
8.773(4); b(Å ): 18.152(8); c(Å ): 17.899(8); α(deg): 90; β(deg):
92.966(9); γ(deg): 90; V(Å 3): 2846.55; Z: 3; F(000): 1222; GOF: 1.01;
Final R1: 0.0778; Final wR2: 0.1985.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Crystal Engineering: Lattice Inclusion Based on O-H···O Hydrogen-Bonded
Self-Assembly and Guest-Induced Structural Mimicry
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

Jarugu Narasimha

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 141-78-6
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM In a typical experiment, the host TP2 (50.0 mg, 0.07 mmol) was dissolved
in 20 mL of ethyl acetate/methanol, and a few drops of guests was
introduced without causing precipitation. The resultant solution was
allowed to evaporate over a period of 7-10 days to yield colorless
crystals quantitatively. The crystals were characterized by 1H NMR, TGA,
and X-ray crystallography. A similar procedure was used for the synthesis
of inclusion compounds of BX. TP2·benzene;
(TP2=1,3,6,8-Tetrakis(2,6-dimethyl-4-hydroxyphenyl)pyrene). Formula:
C72H66O4; FW: 995.3; Crystal system: Monoclinic; SG: P21; a(Å ):
17.4544(18); b(Å ): 18.217(2); c(Å ): 17.9014(18); α(deg): 90; β(deg):
94.161(2): γ(deg); 90: V(Å 3)5677.05; Z: 4; F(000): 2036; GOF: 1.001;
Final R1:0.0626; Final wR2: 0.1474.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Crystal Engineering: Lattice Inclusion Based on O-H···O Hydrogen-Bonded
Self-Assembly and Guest-Induced Structural Mimicry
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Bajpai, Alankriti; Natarajan, Palani; Venugopalan, Paloth; Moorthy,
Jarugu Narasimha
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2012), 77(18), 7858-7865

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: In a typical experiment, the host TP2 (50.0
mg, 0.07 mmol) was dissolved in 20 mL of ethyl acetate/methanol, and a
few drops of guests was introduced without causing precipitation. The
resultant solution was allowed to evaporate over a period of 7-10 days to
yield colorless crystals quantitatively. The crystals were characterized
by 1H NMR, TGA, and X-ray crystallography. A similar procedure was used
for the synthesis of inclusion compounds of BX. BX·benzene;
(BX=2,4-Bis(4-hydroxy-2,6-dimethylphenyl)-1,5-dimethylbenzene). Formula:
C30H32O2; FW: 424.58; Crystal system: Monoclinic; SG: P21/c; a(Å ):
8.2485(12); b(Å ): 18.038(3); c(Å ): 18.437(3); α(deg): 90; β(deg):
98.360(3); γ(deg): 90; V(Å 3): 2714.03; Z: 4; F(000): 912; GOF: 1.039;
Final R1: 0.0759; Final wR2: 0.2181.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Crystal Engineering: Lattice Inclusion Based on O-H···O Hydrogen-Bonded
Self-Assembly and Guest-Induced Structural Mimicry
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

Jarugu Narasimha
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2012), 77(18), 7858-7865

$DATUM 7732-18-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM (5-Bromo-2-chloro-3-hydroxyphenyl)(phenyl)methanone (166). To a
suspension of compound 56 (6.0 g, 22.6 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (100 mL) were
added oxalyl chloride (2.4 mL, 27.1 mmol) and catalytic amounts of DMF at
room temperature. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 2
hours. The mixture was evaporated in vacuo and dried under high vacuum.
The crude acid chloride was dissolved with benzene (100 mL) and cooled to
0 °C. To the reaction mixture was added AlCl3 (6.9 g, 52.0 mmol)
portionwise at 0 °C. The mixture was stirred at 90 °C for 15 hours. The
mixture was cooled to rt and evaporated in vacuo. The residue was cooled
to 0 °C and aq. 1N HCl solution was added. The mixture was extracted with
EtOAc (150 mL × 1). The organic layer was dried over MgSO4, filtered, and
concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by silica gel column
chromatography. Yield: (7.33 g, quatitative). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ
7.85-7.82 (m, 2H), 7.70-7.64 (m, 1H), 7.55-7.49 (m, 2H), 7.37 (d, J = 2.2
Hz, 1H), 7.13 (d, J = 2.2 Hz, 1H), 5.94 (s, 1H).

= 7.6 Hz, 2H, Ar-H), 7.16 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 4H, Ar-H), 6.59 (s, 2H,

139.6, 128.8, 123.6, 119.6, 89.1 (η6-C6H5), 29.2, 24.7, 23.7. Anal. Calcd

$DATUM Reaction of [Ru(xantsil)(CO)(η6-toluene)] (1a) with Benzene. Colorless
crystals of 1a (10.0 mg, 0.0183 mmol) were dissolved in benzene (5 mL).
After stirring for 3 h at room temperature, the solution was evaporated
to dryness to give an analytically pure sample of
[Ru(xantsil)(CO)(η6-C6H6)] (1b) as a white powder. Yield: 9.7 mg (100%)
[Ru(xantsil)(CO)(η6-C6H6)] (1b), yield : 9.7 mg 100 % Anal. Calcd for
C26H30O2Si2Ru: C, 58.73; H, 5.69. Found: 58.56; H, 5.89. MS (FAB,
m-nitrobenzyl alcohol): m/z 532 (M+, 22), 454 (M+ - benzene, 100). 1H NMR
(300 MHz, C6D12): δ 0.57, 0.64 (s, 6H × 2, SiMe2), 1.39, 1.78 (s, 3H × 2,
9,9′-CMe2), 4.98 (s, 6H, η6-C6H6), 7.00–7.26 (m, 6H, xanthene). 13C{1H}
NMR (75.5 MHz, C6D12): δ 4.6, 9.8 (SiMe2), 22.8, 31.0 (9,9′-CMe2), 36.5
(9,9′-CMe2), 97.2 (η6-C6H6), 122.9, 124.1, 129.6, 134.1, 138.3, 159.0
(xanthene), 201.2 (CO). 29Si{1H} NMR (59.6 MHz, C6D12): δ 13.3. IR (KBr,
cm-1): 1911vs (νCO).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for Pd(OAc)2-catalyzed
oxidative cross-coupling of polyfluoroarenes with benzene. Under air
atmosphere, Pd(OAc)2 (0.06 mmol, 14 mg) and Ag2CO3 (0.90 mmol, 248 mg)
were added into a dried Schlenk tube. The tube was stopped and degassed
with N2 for three times. Then HOAc (0.60 mmol, 36 mg), polyfluoroarene 1
(0.60 mmol), and diisopropyl sulfide (0.60 mmol, 71 mg) were added by
syringe, followed by benzene (4.0 mL, 75 equiv). The mixture was stirred
under N2 atmosphere at 120 °C for 20 h (unless otherwise specified), and
then cooled down to room temperature. The resultant mixture was filtered
through a short plug of silica gel and then concentrated in vacuo. The
product 3 was further purified through flash chromatography on silica gel
with petroleum ether. 2,3,5,6-Tetrafluoro-4-methoxybiphenyl (3b). This
compound was prepared according to the general procedure described above
using 110 mg 2,3,5,6-tetrafluoroanisole with benzene, and purified by
flash chromatography to afford 133 mg white crystal with 86% yield. When
the reaction was conducted under an air atmosphere, using 108 mg
2,3,5,6-tetrafluoroanisole with benzene afforded 117 mg 3b with 76%
yield. R f = 0.48 (petroleum ether). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 4.07
(s, 3H), 7.37-7.48 (m, 5H). 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 62.0 (t, J F =
4.2), 114.2 (t, J F = 16.9), 127.2, 128.5, 128.8, 130.1, 138.4 (dm, J F =
145.4), 141.1 (dm, J F = 226.4), 144.4 (dm, J F = 225.8). 19F NMR (283
MHz, CDCl3): δ = -80.4 (dd, J F = 7.6, 22.4, 2F), -67.4 (dd, J F = 7.1,
22.1, 2F). MS (EI): found: 256 (M+), calcd for C13H8F4O (M+): 256.05.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM reaction run under an atmosphere of air gave lower yield
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Palladium-Catalyzed Cross-Coupling of Polyfluoroarenes with Simple Arenes
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Li, Hu; Liu, Jia; Sun, Chang-Liang; Li, Bi-Jie; Shi, Zhang-Jie
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Organic Letters (2011), 13(2), 276-279

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General procedure for Pd(OAc)2-catalyzed oxidative cross-coupling of
polyfluoroarenes with benzene. Under air atmosphere, Pd(OAc)2 (0.06 mmol,
14 mg) and Ag2CO3 (0.90 mmol, 248 mg) were added into a dried Schlenk
tube. The tube was stopped and degassed with N2 for three times. Then
HOAc (0.60 mmol, 36 mg), polyfluoroarene 1 (0.60 mmol), and diisopropyl
sulfide (0.60 mmol, 71 mg) were added by syringe, followed by benzene
(4.0 mL, 75 equiv). The mixture was stirred under N2 atmosphere at 120 °C
for 20 h (unless otherwise specified), and then cooled down to room
temperature. The resultant mixture was filtered through a short plug of
silica gel and then concentrated in vacuo. The product 3 was further
purified through flash chromatography on silica gel with petroleum ether.
2,3,4,5,6-Pentafluorobiphenyl (3a). This compound was prepared according
to the general procedure described above using 101 mg pentafluorobenzene
with benzene, and purified by flash chromatography to afford 134 mg white
crystal with 91% yield. When the reaction was conducted under an air
atmosphere, using 101 mg pentafluorobenzene with benzene afforded 124 mg
3a with 85% yield. R f = 0.85 (petroleum ether). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3):
δ = 7.40-7.43 (m, 2H), 7.45-7.48 (m, 2H), 7.49-7.53 (m, 1H). 13C NMR (100
MHz, CDCl3): δ = 115.6 (m), 126.4, 128.7, 129.3, 130.1, 137.8 (dm, J F =
253.3), 140.4 (dm, J F = 253.0), 144.2 (dm, J F = 245.7). 19F NMR (283
MHz, CDCl3): δ = -84.6~-84.4 (m, 2F), -77.9 (t, J F = 20.8, 1F), -65.5
(dd, J F = 7.4, 23.5, 2F). MS (EI): found: 244 (M+), calcd for C12H5F5
(M+): 244.03.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM alternative preparation shown, reaction run under an atmosphere of air
gave lower yield, optimization study (optimized on oxidant, acid and
additive)
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Palladium-Catalyzed Cross-Coupling of Polyfluoroarenes with Simple Arenes
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Li, Hu; Liu, Jia; Sun, Chang-Liang; Li, Bi-Jie; Shi, Zhang-Jie
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Organic Letters (2011), 13(2), 276-279

$DATUM Synthesis of [Me2Si(C5Me4)2]W(Ph)H A suspension of
[Me2Si(C5Me4)(C5Me3CH2)]WH (15 mg, 0.03 mmol) in benzene (0.7 mL) was
heated at 140°C overnight in a sealed tube. After this period, the
volatile components were removed in vacuo to give yellow
[Me2Si(C5Me4)2]W(Ph)H in quantitative yield as observed by 1H NMR
spectroscopy. [Me2Si(C5Me4)2]W(Ph)H

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Reaction of [Ir(PNP)(COE)][PF6] (1) with Benzene. Formation of
[Ir(PNP)(H)(Ph)][PF6] (2). A solution (3 mL) of complex 1 (15 mg, 0.039
mmol) in benzene was heated at 60 °C for 1 h, during which the color
changed to orange. The solvent was evaporated and the orange solid was
washed with pentane and dried under vacuum overnight, resulting in pure
complex 2 in quantitative yield. Compound 2 was obtained also by
dissolving complex 1 in benzene and leaving it for 4 days at room
temperature. 31P{1H} NMR (hydride coupled, CD2Cl2): 54.00 (d, 2JHP = 10.0
Hz), -150.0 (heptet, 1JFP = 713 Hz, PF6). 1H NMR (CD2Cl2): -43.9 (vt,
2JPH = 12 Hz, 1H, H-Ir), 1.18 (dd, 5JPH = 6.9 Hz, 3JPH = 14.2 Hz, 18H,
P-C(CH3)3), 3.90 (m, 4H, CH2-P), 6.80 (t, 2JHH = 7.3 Hz, 1H, aryl-H),
6.93 (t, 2JHH = 6.2 Hz, 1H, aryl-H), 7.06 (t, 2JHH = 7.3 Hz, 1H, aryl-H),
7.32 (d, JHH = 7.6 Hz 2H, aryl-H), 7.7 (d, JHH = 7.8 Hz, 2H, H-PNP-aryl),
7.96 (t, JHH = 7.8 Hz, 1H, H-PNP-aryl). Assignment of signals was
confirmed by COSY. NOE effect was observed between hydride at -43.9 ppm
and protons at 7.32 ppm. 13C{1H} NMR (CD2Cl2): 27.9-29.6 (m, P-C(CH3)3),
36 (m, CH2P), 122.4 (m, PNP-aryl C3,5), 126.1-136.4 (singlets, phenyl
carbons), 139.6 (s, PNP-aryl, C4), 145 (br t, Cipso), 163.9 (s, PNP-aryl,
C2,6). Assignment of the signals was confirmed by DEPT. Anal. Calcd for
C29H49P3F6NIr: C, 42.96; H, 6.09. Found: C, 44.93; H, 6.69.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

An experimental and theoretical study

$DATUM Reaction of [Ir(PNP)(COE)][PF6] (1) with benzene. Formation of
[Ir(PNP)(H)(Ph)][PF6] (2). A solution (3mL) of complex 1 (15mg, 0.039
mmol) in benzene was heated at 60°C for 1 hr during which the color
changed to orange. The solvent was evaporated and the orange solid was
washed with pentane and dried under vacuum overnight resulting in pure
complex 2 in quantitative yield. Compound 2 was obtained also by
dissolving compound 1 in benzene and leaving it for 4 days at room
temperature. 31P{1H}NMR (hydride coupled, CD2Cl2): 54.00 (d, 2JHP = 10.00
Hz ), -150.0 (heptet, 1JFP = 713 Hz , PF6). 1H NMR (CD2Cl2): -43.9 (t,
2JPH = 12 Hz, 1H, H-Ir), 1.18 (dd, 5JPH = 6.93 Hz , 3JPH = 14.16 Hz,
P-C(CH 3)3, 36H), 3.90 (m, 4H, CH 2-P), 6.80 (t, 2JHH = 7.3 Hz , H-aryl),
6.93 (t, 2JHH = 6.2 Hz, H-aryl), 7.06 (t, 2JHH = 7.3 Hz, H-aryl), 7.32
(d, JHH = 7.6 Hz H-aryl), 7.7 (d, JHH = 7.83 Hz, PNP-aryl H), 7.96 (t,
JHH = 7.83, PNParyl H). 13C{1H}NMR (CD2Cl2): 27.9-29.6 (m, P-C(CH3)3), 36
(m, CH2P), 122.4 (m, PNP-aryl, C3,5), 126.1-136.4 (singlets, C-aryl),
139.6 (s, PNP-aryl C4), 145 (broad triplet, Cipso), 163.9 (s, PNP-aryl
C2,6).

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Synthetic Procedure (Products 2, 12,
14, 16, 22, 24, 26, 28): Approximately 0.2 g of the amide (ca. 1 mmol) is
dissolved in 1 mL arene and 4 mL of triflic acid is added. The mixture is
stirred for 6 hrs at 25°C and poured over about 15 g of ice. The
resulting mixture is extracted twice with CHCl3 and the organic extracts
are washed with water, then brine, and dried over MgSO4. Concentration
with reduced pressure then gives the products; if necessary, column
chromatography is done over silica. 22, yield 98%
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

$DATUM [0390] Step D: To a mixture of the lactam (3.0 g, 16 mmol) from step C
above and benzene (9.0 mL, 0.10 mol) was added triflic acid (24.0 mL,
0.27 mol). The reaction solution was stirred at room temperature for 5
hours and then it was diluted with water and extracted with
dichloromethane (3×). The combined organic extracts were dried over
sodium sulfate and concentrated in vacuo to give the desired

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Example 678: 1-Methoxy-4-(phenylsulfonyl)benzene Step a A stirred
solution of benzene (10 mL, 100 mmol) and 4-methoxybenzenesulfonyl
chloride (4.12 g, 20 mmol) was cooled to -40 °C and treated slowly under
nitrogen with solid anhydrous aluminum chloride (3.2 g, 24 mmol). After
stirring neat for 4 hours at room temperature, the mixture was slowly
poured into cold 1N hydrochloric acid and extracted with ethyl acetate
(2x). The organic phase was washed with a saturated, aqueous sodium
chloride solution, dried over anhydrous sodium sulfate, and filtered
through a short column of silica gel. The filtrate was evaporated in
vacuo to yield 1-methoxy-4-(phenylsulfonyl)benzene (4.96 g, 100%) as a
homogeneous oil which solidified on standing.
1-Methoxy-4-(phenylsulfonyl)benzene, yield (4.96 g, 100%)

$DATUM 71-43-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Procedure for the Arylation of Alkynes:
Approximately 0.2 g of alkyne (ca. 1 mmol) is dissolved in 1 mL C6H6 and
4 mL of triflic acid is added (NOTE: if the amino-alkyne is used as a HCl
or HBr salt, the reaction vessel should be equipped with a vent to
release HCl or HBr gas). The mixture is stirred for 6 hrs and poured over
about 15 g of ice. The resulting mixture is made basic with 50% NaOH and
extracted twice with CHCl3. The organic extracts are washed with water,
then brine, and dried over MgSO4. Concentration with reduced pressure
then gives the products; if necessary, column chromatography is done over
silica. Product 27; Clear oil 1H NMR, 300 MHz, CDCl3, δ: 2.23 (s, 3H),
3.30 (s, 2H), 6.60-6.71 (m, 2H), 6.78-6.81 (m, 1H), 7.07-7.12 (m, 1H),
7.21-7.35(m, 10H). 13C NMR, 125 MHz, CDCl3, δ: 27.8, 52.0, 117.9, 118.5,
126.6, 127.9, 128.5, 128.7, 129.7, 133.3, 145.0, 146.9; EI-MS, m/z: 273
(M+), 258, 180, 165, 77. HRMS, calcd for C20H19N: 273.151750, found
273.150783
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM regioselective, Friedel-Crafts-type reaction
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Reactive Dications: The Superacid-Catalyzed Reactions of Alkynes Bearing
Adjacent N-Heterocycles or Amine Groups
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Klumpp, Douglas A.; Rendy, Rendy; Zhang, Yun; McElrea, Aaron; Gomez,
Alma; Dang, Han
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2004), 69(23), 8108-8110

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure B: Arylation of phenyl
dimethylcarbamate (1b) with o-dichlorobenzene under O2 In a 25 mL Schlenk
tube equipped with a Teflon stopcock was added phenyl dimethylcarbamate
(1b) (33.0 mg, 0.2 mmol) and Pd(OAc)2 (4.5 mg, 0.02 mmol, 10 mol%). The
tube was evacuated and refilled with O2 three times. Dimethylsulfoxide
(0.04 mmol, 20 mol%), dichlorobenzene (1 mL) and trifluoroacetic acid (76
μL, 1 mmol) was added sequentially. The tube was sealed and the mixture
was stirred on a heating block at 70 °C for 48 h. After cooling to
ambient temperature, GC-FID analysis was conducted using dodecane (23 μL,
0.1 mmol) as internal standard. Only monoarylated product 2b was afforded
in 27% GC-yield. Using 0.5 mL benzene and 0.5 mL benzene-d6, 2t and its
isotopomer 2t-d5 was isolated in 99% with a ratio of 3.9:1 after 47 h.
Orange oil. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.35-7.27 (m, 3.36H), 7.24-7.15 (m,
1.87H), 7.00-6.95 (m, 2H), 2.80 (s, 3H), 2.79 (s, 3H), 2.30 (s, 3H).
13C{1H} NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3) δ 154.8, 148.3, 138.5, 138.0, 131.9, 130.4,
129.1, 128.0, 127.0, 126.5, 123.9, 36.7, 36.3, 21.1. HRMS (ESI) m/z
calc'd for C16H18NO2 [M+H]+: 256.1332; found: 256.1327; calc'd for
C16H13D5NO2 [M+H]+: 261.1645; found 261.1635.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM regioselective
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

Arenes and Sodium Persulfate
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of the American Chemical Society (2010), 132(16), 5837-5844

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Synthetic Procedure (Products 14-26).
Approximately 0.2 g of the olefin is suspended in 2 mL of benzene and 3
mL of TfOH is added. After being stirred for at least 3 h, the mixture is
poured over ice, and it is made basic with concentrated NaOH. The mixture
is then extracted with CHCl3 and the organic phase is washed with brine,
dried with MgSO4, and concentrated under vacuum. 19, yield 99%

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Reaction of Quinoline and Isoquinoline
Aldehydes with Arenes; General Procedure. The heterocyclic aldehyde (0.2
g) was dissolved in benzene (1 mL) or the corresponding arene (1 mL, for
19 and 20) and CF3SO3H (2 mL) and the mixture was stirred at r.t. for 3
h. The mixture was then poured over ice and the resulting solution was
made basic by slow addition of aq 50% NaOH solution. The products were
then extracted into CHCl3, the organic phase was washed with H2O then
brine, dried (MgSO4), and the product was isolated by removal of solvent
from under vacuum. 4-(Diphenylmethyl)-3-phenylquinoline, yield 99%. Mp
148-151 °C. 1H NMR (CDCl3/TMS): δ = 6.31 (s, 1 H), 7.16-7.52 (m, 16 H),
6.73 (m, 1 H), 7.98 (m, 2 H), 8.22 (d, 1 H, J = 8.7 Hz). 13C NMR
(CDCl3/TMS): δ = 52.9, 119.9, 120.0, 124.0, 126.2, 126.3, 126.9, 127.4,
127.6, 128.6, 129.2, 129.5, 130.4, 139.7, 142.1, 148.6, 150.1, 156.8.
EI-MS: m/z = 371 (M+).Anal. calcd for C28H21N: C, 90.53, H, 5.70. Found:
C, 91.00, H, 5.76.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

arenes

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Synthesis of [(η6-benzene)Ni(IPr*)] (BNI*). A reaction tube was charged
with Ni(cod)2 (10.8 mg, 0.04 mmol), IPr* (36.2 mg, 0.04 mmol), and
benzene (0.5 mL). The resulting solution was transferred into an
autoclave reactor, and then H2 was pressurized at 5 atm. After the
reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 3 h, the resultant
brown solution was quickly filtered, and all volatiles were removed under
reduced pressure to give BNI*. A single crystal suitable for X-ray
diffraction analysis was prepared by recrystallization from benzene/
hexane at -35 °C. Reddish brown solid, yield 40.3 mg, 0.038 mmol, 99%. 1H
NMR (400 MHz, THF-d8, -60 °C; Figure S3, Supporting Information): δ
7.41-7.35 (m, 16H, Ar-H), 7.26 (t, J = 6.2 Hz, 4H, Ar-H), 7.08-7.01 (m,
16H, Ar-H), 6.82 (d, J = 7.2 Hz, 8H, Ar-H), 5.40 (s, 4H, CHPh2), 5.26 (s,
6H, η6-C6H6), 4.96 (s, 2H, NC2H2N), 2.29 (s, 6H, CH3). 13C{1H} NMR (100
MHz, THF-d8, -60 °C): δ 194.2, 145.6, 144.8, 142.5, 138.7, 138.1, 131.2,
130.1, 129.7, 128.9, 128.8, 127.1, 126.8, 120.1, 89.9 (η6-C6H6), 52.2,
21.8. Anal. Calcd for C75H62N2Ni: C, 85.79; H, 5.95; N, 2.67. Found: C,
85.42; H, 6.03; N, 3.05. empirical formula: C75H56N2Ni, 0.5(C6H6);
formula weight: 1082.98; cryst. System: orthorhombic; space group: Pbca
(#61); a: 20.0859(15)Å; b: 24.0588(16)Å; c: 28.841(2)Å; α : 90 °;β : 90°;
γ : 90°; volume: 13937.1(17)Å3; Z: 8; calculated density: 1.032 Mg m-3;
2θmax: 50.0deg.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM benzene also used as solvent, autoclave used, alternative preparation
shown
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM One-pot, single-step, and gram-scale synthesis of mononuclear
[(η6-arene)Ni(N-heterocyclic carbene)] complexes: useful precursors of
the Ni0-NHC unit

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Diaryl Ketone Synthesis, General Procedure.
Trifluoromethanesulfonic acid (0.35 mL, 4 mmol) was added to a solution
of amide 17 (0.24 g, 1 mmol) and the arene (1 mmol) in anhydrous CH2Cl2
(2 mL). The mixture was stirred for 3 h at 50 °C and then poured over
ice. The products were extracted into CHCl3, and the organic solution was
washed with H2O (2×) and brine (2×) and dried over anhydrous sodium
sulfate. The crude product was isolated and purified via column
chromatography (hexane/ethyl acetate). Note: ketones 19 and 22 were
prepared using the corresponding arene as solvent. Yield 99%. Compound
21.

$DATUM 1493-13-6
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Preparation of Condensation Products 12-15 and
17-19 The 1,2-Indandione (1 mmol) is dissolved in CH2Cl2 (5 mL) and the
aromatic compound (1 mL) is added. The vessel is purged with Ar and then
triflic acid (1 mL, 11 mmol) is slowly added to the solution with
stirring. After 3 h, the mixture is poured over ice. The resulting
mixture is extracted twice with chloroform and the organic extracts are
combined. The organic solution is washed with water (2 x ) and then brine
(2x) and dried over anhydrous sodium sulfate. Filtration and removal of
the solvent provides the crude condensation product. In some cases, the
resulting product is greater than 95% pure (GC analysis) and requires no
further purification. However, mixtures were purified by flash
chromatography (hexanes-ether). 2,2-diphenyl-1-indanone (12) Table 1.
Analytical data for condensation products 13-15 and 17-19 Compound 19
Yield 99%. Mp: 114-117 °C 1H NMR CDCl3, δ:3.90 (s, 1H), 7.24-7.38 (m,
11H), 7.79 (d, 1H, J=7.5 Hz), 7.84 (dd, 1H, J=7.8, 8.7 Hz). 13C NMR
CDCl3, δ: 45.6, 62.9, 121.4, 124.0, 127.0, 128.6, 129.8, 137.6, 138.0,
142.9, 151.7, 204.6 Mass spectrum (low res.; EI): 364/362 (M+), 284, 265,
252, 178 Mass spectrum (high res.; EI): Calcd. For C21H15OBr, 362.03063;
found 362.03151.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM regioselective
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Superacid-Promoted Hydroxyalkylation of 1,2-Indandiones
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Tracy, Adam F.; Abbott, Matthew P.; Klumpp, Douglas A.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthetic Communications (2013), 43(16), 2171-2177

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAS_Reaction_Number
$DATUM 31-562-CAS-14359214

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES

$DATUM 99
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Preparation of Tp′Rh(PMe3)(R)H (3a-l): General Procedure. Ten milligrams
(0.019 mmol) of 2-Cl was used for the in situ synthesis of 2, which was
then dissolved in 0.4 mL of the corresponding RH and transferred to a
resealable 5 mm NMR tube. After the reaction was complete at room
temperature, the solvent was removed in vacuo, and the resulting residue
was dissolved in C6D6. For activation of 1,1,1-trifluoroethane,
fluoromethane, and difluoromethane, 2 was dissolved in 0.4 mL of C6D12
and transferred to a high pressure medium wall NMR tube, followed by
pressurization with the corresponding gas at 50 psi. 1H, 11B{1H},
13C{1H}, 19F, and 31P{1H} NMR spectra were collected. The yields are
almost quantitative except those for fluoromethane and difluoromethane.
For Tp′Rh(PMe3)(C6H5)H (3a). Reaction was complete after overnight
incubation. The volatiles were removed to give a pale yellow solid, which
was dissolved in C6D6. 1H NMR resonances were reported in ref 40. 31P{1H}
NMR (400 MHz, C6D6): δ 3.24 (d, 1 J Rh-P = 145.8 Hz).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM in-situ generated reactant, benzene used also as solvent
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Kinetic and Thermodynamic Selectivity of Intermolecular C-H Activation at
[Tp'Rh(PMe3)]. How Does the Ancillary Ligand Affect the Metal-Carbon Bond
Strength?
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Jiao, Yunzhe; Morris, James; Brennessel, William W.; Jones, William D.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of the American Chemical Society (2013), 135(43), 16198-16212

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Preparation of amino alcohol products: 1.0 mL
of benzene and 4.0 mL of CF3SO3H are combined in a vial and 0.2 g of the
amino alcohol is added. The mixture is stirred for 3-6 hours and then
poured over about 20 g of ice. The resulting solution is neutralized with
50% NaOH, extacted into CHCl3, and the organic phase is washed with
water, then brine, and dried with MgSO4. Concentration under reduced
pressure provide crude products. In most cases, the crude products show a
high level of purity by NMR and GC analysis. If necessary, the product(s)
can be further purified by column chromatography or distillation. This
procedure has not been optimized. 19, yield 99% 1H NMR (CHCl3, 125 MHz),
δ: 1.60 (d, 3H, J = 7.2 Hz), 3.59 (s, 2H), 4.05 (q, 1H, J = 7.8 Hz), 6.52
(m, 2H), 6.64 (d, 1H, J = 7.8 Hz), 7.08 (m, 1H), 7.18-7.29 (m, 5H); 13C
NMR (CHCl3, 125 MHz), δ: 22.0, 44.9, 113.2, 114.8, 118.3, 126.2, 127.9,
128.6, 129.5, 146.6, 146.7, 147.9; MS: 197 (M+)

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Synthetic Procedure (Products 2, 12,
14, 16, 22, 24, 26, 28): Approximately 0.2 g of the amide (ca. 1 mmol) is
dissolved in 1 mL arene and 4 mL of triflic acid is added. The mixture is
stirred for 6 hrs at 25°C and poured over about 15 g of ice. The
resulting mixture is extracted twice with CHCl3 and the organic extracts
are washed with water, then brine, and dried over MgSO4. Concentration
with reduced pressure then gives the products; if necessary, column
chromatography is done over silica. 1-Benzoyl-4,4-diphenylpiperidone
(12), yield 99% MP (80% hexane:20% CHCl3): 178-179°C; 1H NMR (300 MHz,
CHCl3) δ, ppm: 2.30-2.40 (m, 2H), 2.40-2.55 (m, 2H), 3.35-3.52 (m, 2H),
3.76-3.91 (m, 2H), 7.04 - 7.40 (m, 15H); 13C NMR (125 MHz, CHCl3) δ, ppm:
36.0, 37.0, 39.5, 45.2, 126.4, 127.1, 128.7, 128.9, 129.7, 136.4, 146.5,
170.5; EI MS 341 (M+).

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Preparation of Condensation Products 12-15 and
17-19 The 1,2-Indandione (1 mmol) is dissolved in CH2Cl2 (5 mL) and the
aromatic compound (1 mL) is added. The vessel is purged with Ar and then
triflic acid (1 mL, 11 mmol) is slowly added to the solution with
stirring. After 3 h, the mixture is poured over ice. The resulting
mixture is extracted twice with chloroform and the organic extracts are
combined. The organic solution is washed with water (2 x ) and then brine
(2x) and dried over anhydrous sodium sulfate. Filtration and removal of
the solvent provides the crude condensation product. In some cases, the
resulting product is greater than 95% pure (GC analysis) and requires no
further purification. However, mixtures were purified by flash
chromatography (hexanes-ether). 2,2-diphenyl-1-indanone (12) Table 1.
Analytical data for condensation products 13-15 and 17-19 Compound 17
Yield 99%. Mp: 151-154 °C 1H NMR CDCl3, δ:3.86 (s, 3H), 3.87 (s, 2H),
7.25-7.33 (m, 12H), 7.44 (d, 1H, J=9.3). 13C NMR CDCl3, δ: 44.3, 55.6,
63.6, 106.2, 124.8, 126.6, 126.7, 128.2, 129.4, 136.9, 143.6, 144.9,
159.8, 205.3 Mass spectrum (low res.; EI): 314 (M+), 253, 237, 223, 165.
Mass spectrum (high res.; EI): Calcd. For C22H18O2, 314.13068; found
314.13160.

$DATUM Tracy, Adam F.; Abbott, Matthew P.; Klumpp, Douglas A.

$DATUM 7732-18-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The imidazole substrate (0.1 g) is dissolved
in benzene (or other arene; 1.0 mL) and CF3SO3H(1-2 mL) is added. The
reaction is stirred at least 2 h, and then the mixture is poured over
several grams of ice. The mixture is made basic (pH paper) with the slow
addition of 10 M NaOH. The resulting solution is extracted twice with
CHCl3, and the combined organic extracts are further washed with water
(once) and then brine (twice). If purification is necessary, the product
mixture is subjected to column chromatography (silica gel; hexane/
ether). 7, yield 99%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM superacidic (stage 1)
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Superelectrophilic Chemistry of Imidazoles
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Sheets, Matthew R.; Li, Ang; Bower, Edward A.; Weigel, Andrew R.; Abbott,
Matthew P.; Gallo, Robert M.; Mitton, Adam A.; Klumpp, Douglas A.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2009), 74(6), 2502-2507

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Typical Procedure.
2-Methylamino-1,1-diphenylethane (20). Methylaminoacetaldehyde dimethyl
acetal (12) (0.37 g, 3.11 mmol) was dissolved in 2.0 mL of benzene, and
3.0 mL of TfOH was slowly added. After 4 h of stirring, the mixture was
poured over ice and neutralized with NaOH. The product was then extracted
into CHCl3 and the organic phase washed with water and then brine, dried
with MgSO4, and concentrated in vacuo. PRODUCT 17f 1H NMR (300MHz, CDCl3)
δ: 1.14 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 6H), 2.64 (q, J =7.4 Hz, 4H), 3.15 (d, J = 7.8
Hz, 2H), 3.94 (t, J = 7.8 Hz, 1 H), 7.20-7.40 (m, 10H). 1 3 C NMR (125
MHZ, CDCl3) δ: 11.7, 47.5, 50.0, 58.5, 126.5, 128.5, 1128.6, 144.3. Mass
Spectrum, (e.i.) m/z: 165, 86

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: III. Experimental Procedure for the Oxidative
Amination with Various Nitrogen Sources: To a 5 mL screw-capped vial
equipped with a 15 x 10 mm spinvane triangular-shaped Teflon stirbar,
were added imide (0.3 mmol, 1 equiv), PhI(OAc)2 (483 mg, 1.5 mmol, 5
equiv) and benzene (1.5 mL). The resulting mixture was sealed with a
Teflon-lined cap and stirred at 140 °C for 4 h in an oil bath with
vigorous stirring. The reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature,
filtered through a plug of silica and washed with EtOAc (30 mL). The
filtrate was concentrated, and evaporated to dryness under high vacuum.
The desired product was purified by flash column chromatography using
indicated eluents. N-Phenyl-4-methylphthalimide (Table 2, 3e), light
yellow solid, yield 99%. m.p. 197-199 °C; 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.83
(d, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 7.75 (s, 1H), 7.57 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 7.52-7.48
(m, 2H), 7.44-7.39 (m, 3H), 2.54 (s, 3H); 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3) δ
167.4, 167.3, 145.7, 134.9, 132.1, 131.8, 129.2, 129.0, 127.95, 126.5,
124.2, 123.6, 22.0; IR (Film) 3207, 3168, 3106, 2994, 1700, 1653, 1558,
1539, 1507, 1457, 1379, 1099, 1067 cm-1; HRMS (FAB) m/z calcd. For
C15H11NO2 [M]+: 237.0790, found: 237.0787.

$DATUM Cp*(P(OMe)3)IrPh(OTf). The addition of C6H6 (1.0 g, 13 mmol) to 5 (230
mg, 0.370 mmol) in 7 mL of CH2Cl2 resulted in the darkening of the
reaction solution over 2 h. After 10 h, the solvent was removed in vacuo
to provide Cp*(P(OMe)3)IrPh(OTf) as an orange solid (250 mg, 99% yield).
1H NMR (400 MHz, CD2Cl2, 298 K): δ 7.64 (d, 2JH-H) 7.4 Hz, 2H, o-C6H5),
7.30 (dd, 3JH-H ) 7.4 and 7.6 Hz, 2H, m-C6H5), 7.08 (t, 3JH-H) 7.6 Hz,
1H, p-C6H5), 3.67 (d, 2JP-H) 11.2 Hz, 9H, P(OMe)3), δ 1.74 (d, 4JP-H) 2.7
Hz, 15H, C5Me5). 13C{1H} NMR (101 MHz, CD2Cl2, 298 K): δ 140.1 (d, 2JP-C)
15.3 Hz, i-C6H5), 130.7 (s, o-C6H5), 128.0 (s, m-C6H5), 123.2 (s,
p-C6H5), 96.1 (s, C5Me5), 52.5 (s, P(OMe)3), 8.94 (s, C5Me5). 31P{1H} NMR
(162 MHz, CD2Cl2, 298 K): δ 94.2 (s). 19F NMR (377 MHz, CD2Cl2, 298 K):
δ-78.5 (s). HRMS (EI) m/z for[C20H29O6F3 PSIr]+ (M+): calcd 678.1004,
obsd 678.1006.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Synthetic Procedure (Products 2, 12,
14, 16, 22, 24, 26, 28): Approximately 0.2 g of the amide (ca. 1 mmol) is
dissolved in 1 mL arene and 4 mL of triflic acid is added. The mixture is
stirred for 6 hrs at 25°C and poured over about 15 g of ice. The
resulting mixture is extracted twice with CHCl3 and the organic extracts
are washed with water, then brine, and dried over MgSO4. Concentration
with reduced pressure then gives the products; if necessary, column
chromatography is done over silica.
3,3-Diphenyl-1-piperidin-1-yl-propan-1-one (24), yield 99% MP (80%
hexane:20% CHCl3): 122-124°C; 1H NMR (300 MHz, CHCl3) δ, ppm 1.30-1.45
(m, 4H), 1.50-1.57 (m, 2H), 3.15 (d, J = 7.5 Hz, 2H), 3.32-3.45 (m, 4H),
4.72 (t, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 7.13-7.29 (m, 10H); 13C NMR (125 MHz, CHCl3) δ,
ppm 24.6, 26.1, 38.8, 45.1, 47.7, 126.6, 128.1, 128.7, 144.3, 170.0; EI
MS 293 (M+).

$DATUM 7732-18-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Reaction of Quinoline and Isoquinoline
Aldehydes with Arenes; General Procedure. The heterocyclic aldehyde (0.2
g) was dissolved in benzene (1 mL) or the corresponding arene (1 mL, for
19 and 20) and CF3SO3H (2 mL) and the mixture was stirred at r.t. for 3
h. The mixture was then poured over ice and the resulting solution was
made basic by slow addition of aq 50% NaOH solution. The products were
then extracted into CHCl3, the organic phase was washed with H2O then
brine, dried (MgSO4), and the product was isolated by removal of solvent
from under vacuum. 3-(Diphenylmethyl)isoquinoline, yield 99%. Mp 146-149
°C. 1H NMR (CDCl3/TMS): δ = 5.85 (s, 1 H), 7.17-7.31 (m, 11 H), 7.52 (m,
1 H), 7.61 (m, 1 H), 7.65 (m, 1 H), 7.91 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 1 H), 9.22 (s, 1
H). 13C NMR (CDCl3/TMS): δ = 59.0, 119.6, 126.5, 126.5, 126.8, 127.1,
127.4, 128.4, 129.5, 130.3, 136.2, 142.9, 152.4, 156.8. EI-MS: m/z = 295
(M+). Anal. Calcd. for C22H17N: C, 89.46%, H, 5.80%. Found: C, 88.97%, H,
5.87%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM The superacid induced condensation of quinolinecarboxaldehydes with
arenes
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Klumpp, Douglas A.; Jones, Andre; Lau, Siufu; De Leon, Sarah; Garza,
Manuel
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthesis (2000), (8), 1117-1120

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General Synthetic Procedure (Products 14-26). Approximately 0.2 g of the
olefin is suspended in 2 mL of benzene and 3 mL of TfOH is added. After
being stirred for at least 3 h, the mixture is poured over ice, and it is
made basic with concentrated NaOH. The mixture is then extracted with
CHCl3 and the organic phase is washed with brine, dried with MgSO4, and
concentrated under vacuum. 14, yield 99%
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM regioselective, Friedel-Crafts alkylation
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Preparation of amino alcohol products: 1.0 mL
of benzene and 4.0 mL of CF3SO3H are combined in a vial and 0.2 g of the
amino alcohol is added. The mixture is stirred for 3-6 hours and then
poured over about 20 g of ice. The resulting solution is neutralized with
50% NaOH, extacted into CHCl3, and the organic phase is washed with
water, then brine, and dried with MgSO4. Concentration under reduced
pressure provide crude products. In most cases, the crude products show a
high level of purity by NMR and GC analysis. If necessary, the product(s)
can be further purified by column chromatography or distillation. This
procedure has not been optimized. 23, yield 99%
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Reactions of Amino Alcohols in Superacid: The Direct Observation of
Dicationic Intermediates and Their Application in Synthesis

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Synthetic Procedure (Products 2, 12,
14, 16, 22, 24, 26, 28): Approximately 0.2 g of the amide (ca. 1 mmol) is
dissolved in 1 mL arene and 4 mL of triflic acid is added. The mixture is
stirred for 6 hrs at 25°C and poured over about 15 g of ice. The
resulting mixture is extracted twice with CHCl3 and the organic extracts
are washed with water, then brine, and dried over MgSO4. Concentration
with reduced pressure then gives the products; if necessary, column
chromatography is done over silica. 3,3-Diphenyl-butyramide (16), yield
99% MP (80% hexane:20% CHCl3): 84-87°C; 1H NMR (300 MHz, CHCl3) δ, ppm
1.81 (s, 3H), 3.05 (s, 2H), 4.58 (s, 1H), 5.35 (s, 1H), 7.00-7.35 (m,
10H); 13C NMR (125 MHz, CHCl3) δ, ppm 27.8, 45.7, 49.1, 126.6, 127.3,
128.6, 148.5, 173.7; EI MS 239 (M+).

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7446-70-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM (E)-1,4-Diphenylbut-2-ene-1,4-dione (6-130): To a suspension of finely
grinded aluminum chloride (50.1 g, 0.375 mol) in 250 mL of benzene was
added, dropwise within 20 minutes, fumaryl chloride (22.2 g, 0.145 mol)
while stirring quickly with a mechanical stirrer. The reaction mixture
was stirred at reflux for 90 minutes after the initial boiling settled.
Additional stirring for 60 minutes was followed as the reaction was
allowed to cool to rt. To 500 mL of ice was added the pasty reaction
mixture followed by stirring to free any lumps, which then was allowed to
sit for 60 minutes. The benzene layer was washed with hot 1 M HCl (2 x
150 mL), hot water (2 x 150 mL), and was then filtered and concentrated
until crystals were visible. Ethanol (250 mL) was added to the mixture
and cooled over ice. The resulting yellow crystals were suction filtered
and washed with cold ethanol to provide 33.9 g of dibenzoylethylene 6-130
in 99 % yield.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The imidazole substrate (0.1 g) is dissolved
in benzene (or other arene; 1.0 mL) and CF3SO3H(1-2 mL) is added. The
reaction is stirred at least 2 h, and then the mixture is poured over
several grams of ice. The mixture is made basic (pH paper) with the slow
addition of 10 M NaOH. The resulting solution is extracted twice with
CHCl3, and the combined organic extracts are further washed with water
(once) and then brine (twice). If purification is necessary, the product
mixture is subjected to column chromatography (silica gel; hexane/
ether). 5-Benzhydryl-4-methyl-1H-imidazole (8). Using general procedure
A, compound 3 is reacted with C6H6 and CF3SO3H. Product 8 is isolated. 1H
NMR (CDCl3): δ 2.07 (s, 3H), 5.39 (s, 1H), 7.10-7.44 (m, 10), 11.7 (m,
1H). 13C NMR (CDCl3): δ 10.0, 48.3, 126.2, 128.4, 129.2, 133.7, 122.5,
145.1. Low resolution MS (EI): 248 (M+), 247, 233, 171. High resolution
MS (EI), C17H16N2 calcd: 248.13135, found 248.13140.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM using sulfuric acid instead of triflic acid gave significantly lower
yield, superacidic (stage 1)

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Photostimulated reaction of iodobenzene 1a:
The reaction was carried out in a 20 mL flame-dried Schlenk tube,
equipped with a nitrogen inlet and magnetic stirrer at room temperature.
DMSO (13 equiv., 0.5 mL) was dried and deoxygenated, then benzene (2)
(150 equiv., 6.7 mL), t-BuOK (3.0 equiv., 0.168 g, 1.5 mmol) and
substrate 1a (1.0 equiv, 0.102 g, 0.5 mmol) were added and the reaction
mixture was irradiated for 1 h. The reaction was quenched with water and
ammonium nitrate in excess. The residue was extracted with ethyl acetate
(4 x 20 mL) and the organic extract was washed with water, dried with
anhydrous Na2SO4 and filtered. The solvent was removed to leave the crude
product. The product 3a was purified by radial thin-layer chromatography
on silica gel eluting with petroleum ether and was isolated.
4-Methoxybiphenyl (3g) as a white solid, yield 97%. 1H NMR (400 MHz,
CDCl3, TMS) δ 7.56 - 7.51 (m, 4H, CH), 7.43 - 7.39 (m, 2H, CH), 7.32 -
7.28 (m, 1H, CH), 7.00 - 6.97 (m, 2H, CH), 3.85 (s, 3H, CH3). 13C NMR
(101 MHz, CDCl3) δ 159.3 (C), 141.0 (C), 133.9 (C), 128.9 (CH), 128.3
(CH), 126.9 (CH), 126.8 (CH), 114.3 (CH), 55.5 (CH3). 1H-1H COSY NMR (400
MHz, CDCl3) δH/δH7.53/7.41, 7.53/7.30, 7.53/6.99, 7.41/7.30. 1H-13C HSQC
NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δH/δC7.53/128.3, 7.53/126.9, 7.41/128.9, 7.30/126.9,
6.99/, 3.85/55.5. 1H-13C HMBC NMR δH/δC7.53/159.3, 7.53/141.0,
7.53/133.9, 7.53/128.2, 7.53/126.9, 7.53/114.3, 7.41/141.0, 7.41/128.8,
7.30/126.9, 6.97/159.3, 6.97/133.9, 6.97/114.3, 3.85/159.3. GC-MS (70eV):
m/z (%):185 (14) [M+ + 1], 184 (100) [M+], 169 (53), 141 (43), 115 (30).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM photochemical, HPI-T lamp used, optimization study (optimized on reaction
time and stoichemistry), sealed tube used
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Room-Temperature Photoinduced Direct C-H-Arylation via Base-Promoted
Homolytic Aromatic Substitution
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Buden, Maria E.; Guastavino, Javier F.; Rossi, Roberto A.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Organic Letters (2013), 15(6), 1174-1177

$DATUM Example 5 (D100016-151,153) Inside a glove box, a 125 mL round-bottom
flask equipped with a stirring bar, reflux condenser, and gas inlet was
charged with 4,4'-dibromo- biphenyl-2,2'-disulfonyl dichloride (10.18 g,
20 mmoles) and aluminum chloride (5.87 g, 44 mmoles). Benzene (14 mL),
and anhydrous nitromethane (40 mL) were added and the mixture stirred
until dissolved. The solution was heated to 100°C for about 8 hours. The
solution was cooled to room temperature and poured onto 200 g ice mixed
with 100 mL hydrochloric acid. The mixture was extracted several times
with dichloromethane. The organic extracts were washed twice with water,
dried with sodium carbonate, filtered, and evaporated to give 11.75 g
(99%). The mixture was purified by column chromatography using silica gel
and dichloromethane to give 8.73 g (74% yield) of
2,2'-bis-benzenesulfonyl-4,4'-dibromo-biphenyl. Rf 0.32

$DATUM Preparation of amino alcohol products: 1.0 mL of benzene and 4.0 mL of
CF3SO3H are combined in a vial and 0.2 g of the amino alcohol is added.
The mixture is stirred for 3-6 hours and then poured over about 20 g of
ice. The resulting solution is neutralized with 50% NaOH, extacted into
CHCl3, and the organic phase is washed with water, then brine, and dried
with MgSO4. Concentration under reduced pressure provide crude products.
In most cases, the crude products show a high level of purity by NMR and
GC analysis. If necessary, the product(s) can be further purified by
column chromatography or distillation. This procedure has not been
optimized. 12, yield 99% 1H NMR (CHCl3, 125 MHz), δ: 1.02 (d, J = 6.3 Hz,
3H), 1.59 (s, 1H), 2.38 (s, 3H), 3.36 (dq, J = 6.0, 10.2 Hz, 1H), 3.75
(d, J = 10.2 Hz, 1H), 7.15-7.40 (m, 10H); 13C NMR (CHCl3, 125 MHz), δ:
18.1, 34.2, 58.1, 59.6, 126.6, 126.9, 128.4, 128.5, 128.8, 129.1, 142.9,
143.5; MS: 210 (M-15)

$DATUM dmPheboxIr(OAc)(C6H5) (2a). A 50 mL Teflon-stoppered reaction vessel was
charged with a stir bar, 1a (150 mg, 0.0239 mmol), and benzene (12.5 ml,
140 mmol). Oxygen was removed from the solution through three
freeze-pump-thaw cycles and then heated at 100 °C. After 1.5 h the
reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature and the volatiles were
removed. The resulting bright orange solid was dried overnight in vacuo.
Complex 2a as a bright orange solid, yield 149 mg, 99%. 1H NMR (CDCl3,
500 MHz): δ 6.63 (1H, Phebox-aryl-H), 6.63 (t, 2H, 3-Ph), 6.55 (t, 1H,
4-Ph), 6.42 (d, 2H, 2-Ph), 4.44 (d, 2H, JHH' = 8.3 Hz, OCH2), 4.36 (d,
2H, JHH'= 8.3 Hz, OCH2), 2.62 (s, 6H, Phebox-CH3), 2.01 (s, 3H, OAc),
1.41 (s, 6H, CH3),1.04 (s, 6H, CH3). 13C NMR (CDCl3, 125 MHz): δ 185.31
(OAc), 179.16 (Ph), 177.08 (C=N),140.39, 134.76 (2-Ph), 125.48
(Phebox-CH), 125.23 (3-Ph), 123.93, 121.95, 120.87 (4-Ph), 82.22
(OCH2C(CH3)2), 66.29 (OCH2C(CH3)2), 26.95 (CH3), 26.85 (CH3), 25.42
(OAc), 18.81 (Phebox-CH3). Anal. Calcd for C26H31N2O4Ir: C, 49.74; H,
4.98; N, 4.46. Found: C, 48.92; H, 4.89; N, 4.36.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The imidazole substrate (0.1 g) is dissolved
in benzene (or other arene; 1.0 mL) and CF3SO3H(1-2 mL) is added. The
reaction is stirred at least 2 h, and then the mixture is poured over
several grams of ice. The mixture is made basic (pH paper) with the slow
addition of 10 M NaOH. The resulting solution is extracted twice with
CHCl3, and the combined organic extracts are further washed with water
(once) and then brine (twice). If purification is necessary, the product
mixture is subjected to column chromatography (silica gel; hexane/
ether). 10, yield 98%
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM superacidic (stage 1)

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 1493-13-6
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 1310-73-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 71-43-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 67-66-3
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7732-18-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General method B, for preparation of biphenyl
derivatives (16-18): The N-heterocyclic alcohol (1.0 mmol) is dissolved
in C6H6 (3 mL) and CF3SO3H (3 mL, 33 mmol) is added to the solution. The
mixture is stirred overnight at 60°C and then the mixture is poured on
ice. CHCl3 (ca. 30 mL) is added and the aqueous layer is made basic with
10 M NaOH. Separation of the organic phase is followed by a second
extraction with CHCl3, and washings with water, and then twice with
saturated brine. The organic solution is dried with MgSO4, filtered, and
concentrated on a rotary evaporator. If necessary, the product may be
further purified by silica gel chromatography (hexanes:ether).
2-(1-(Biphenyl-4-yl)-2,2,2-trifluoroethyl)-1-butyl-1H-imidazole (18):
Using general method B, compound 18 is isolated as a tan solid, Yield 96%
(Rf 0.08, 2:1 hexanes:ethyl ether): MP 73-75°C. 1H NMR, 500 MHz, CDCl3,
δ: 5.80 (q, JH-F = 8.9 Hz, 1H), 7.38-7.41 (m, 1H), 7.45- 7.48 (m, 2H),
7.59-7.64 (m, 4H), 7.65-7.74 (m, 6H), 7.86 (d, J= 8.1 Hz, 1H), 8.14 (d,
J= 8.5 Hz, 1H), 8.76 (d, J= 5.7 Hz, 1H). 13C NMR, 125 MHz, CDCl3, δ: 52.3
(q, JC-F = 27 Hz), 121.0, 124.0, 124.1, 125.8 (q, JC-F = 279 Hz), 126.8,
127.1, 127.4, 127.4, 127.4, 127.9, 128.8, 130.0, 130.3, 132.9, 136.7,

$DATUM 1493-13-6
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Synthetic Procedure: Approximately 0.2
g of the cinnamic acid (ca. 1 mmol) is dissolved in 1 mL arene and 4 mL
of triflic acid is added. The mixture is stirred for 6 hrs and poured
over about 15 g of ice. The resulting mixture is extracted twice with
CHCl3 and the organic extracts are washed with water, then brine, and
dried over MgSO4. Concentration with reduced pressure then gives the
products; if necessary, column chromatography is done over silica. ENTRY
10; PRODUCT: 5c, YIELD 98%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: 3.2. Preparation of the Dipotassium Compounds
1a, 2a, and 3a. The respective oligosilane (1, 2, 3), potassium
tert-butoxide (2 equiv), and 18-crown-6 (2 equiv) were dissolved in a
small amount of benzene. The reaction mixture immediately turned yellow
and finally afforded an intensely red solution from which the product
precipitated within 24 h as highly air and moisture-sensitive dark red
crystals.
1,5-Dipotassium-2,2,3,3,4,4-hexamethyl-1,1,5,5-tetrakis(trimethylsilyl)pentasilane•2
18-crown-6 (3a). Starting from
2,2,3,3,4,4-hexamethyl-1,1,1,3,3,3-hexakis(trimethylsilyl) pentasilane
(3) 3a was obtained in 98% yield. 1H NMR (C6D6,δ ppm): 3.27 (s, 48 H,
CH2O); 0.65 (s, 36 H, SiMe3); 0.60 (s, 18 H, 3x SiMe2). 13C NMR (C6D6, δ
ppm): 70.0 (CH2O); 8.5 (SiMe3); 7.7 (2x SiMe2); 5.4 (SiMe2). 29Si NMR
(C6D6,δ ppm): -4.3 (SiMe3); -23.1 (2x SiMe2); -40.1 (SiMe2); -184.6
(SiK).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

and Heterocyclosilanes

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: 3.2. Preparation of the Dipotassium Compounds
1a, 2a, and 3a. The respective oligosilane (1, 2, 3), potassium
tert-butoxide (2 equiv), and 18-crown-6 (2 equiv) were dissolved in a
small amount of benzene. The reaction mixture immediately turned yellow
and finally afforded an intensely red solution from which the product
precipitated within 24 h as highly air and moisture-sensitive dark red
crystals.
1,4-Dipotassium-2,2,3,3-tetramethyl-1,1,4,4-tetrakis(trimethylsilyl)tetrasilane•2
18-crown-6 (2a). Starting with
2,2,3,3-tetramethyl-1,1,1,4,4,4-hexakis(trimethylsilyl)tetrasilane (2) 2a
was obtained in 98% yield. 1H NMR (C6D6,δ ppm): 3.29 (s, 48 H, CH2O);
0.87 (s, 12 H, SiMe2); 0.77 (s, 36 H, SiMe3). 13C NMR (C6D6,δ ppm): 70.1
(CH2O); 8.8 (SiMe3); 5.5(SiMe2). 29Si (C6D6, δ ppm): -3.7 (SiMe3); -24.5
(SiMe2); -190.2 (SiK).

$DATUM 71-43-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM (2-Bromo-4-benzoyl)toluene (29). To a mixture of AlCl3 (1.46 g, 11.0
mmol) in benzene (16 mL) was added a solution of 3-bromo-4-methylbenzoyl
chloride (2.33 g, 10.0 mmol) in benzene (8 mL) dropwise at room
temperature. This mixture was stirred for 2 h at 50 °C. The mixture was
washed with 3 M HCl (20 mL) and saturated brine (20 mL), and dried over
anhydrous Na2SO4. The residue after rotary evaporation was purified by
column chromatography over silica gel to give 2.7 g of compound 23 (98%).
(2-Bromo-4-benzoyl)toluene (29), yield 2.7 g (98%). 1H NMR (300 MHz,
CDCl3): δ 7.98 (d, J = 1.8 Hz, 1H), 7.78 (d, J = 6.9 Hz, 2H), 7.65 (dd,
J1 = 7.8, J2 = 1.5 Hz, 1H), 7.59 (d, J = 7.5 Hz, 1H), 7.49 (t, J = 7.5
Hz, 2H), 7.35 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 2H) and 2.49 (s, 3H) ppm.

$DATUM (2-bromo-4-benzoyl)toluene (15) To a mixture of AlCl3 (1.46g, 11.0 mmol,
1.1 eq) in benzene (16mL) was added a solution of compound 2 (2.33g,
10.0mmol) in benzene (8mL) dropwise at room temperature. This mixture was
stirred for 2 hours at 50°C. The mixture was washed with 3M HCl (20mL)
and saturated brine (20mL), and dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The residue
after rotary evaporation was purified by column chromatography over
silica gel to give compound 15 (2.7g, 98% yield).
(2-bromo-4-benzoyl)toluene (15), yield (2.7g, 98%) 1H NMR (300 MHz,
CDCl3): δ 7.98 (d, J= 1.8 Hz, 1H), 7.78 (d, J= 6.9 Hz, 2H), 7.65 (dd, J=
7.8 & 1.5 Hz, 1H), 7.59 (d, J= 7.5 Hz, 1H), 7.49 (t, J= 7.5 Hz, 2H), 7.35
(d, J= 8.1 Hz, 2H) and 2.49 (s, 3H) ppm.

1.1 eq) in benzene (16mL) was added a solution of compound 2 (2.33g,
10.0mmol) in benzene (8mL) dropwise at room temperature. This mixture was
stirred for 2 hours at 50°C. The mixture was washed with 3M HCl (20mL)
and saturated brine (20mL), and dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The residue
after rotary evaporation was purified by column chromatography over
silica gel to give compound 15 (2.7g, 98% yield).
(2-bromo-4-benzoyl)toluene (15), yield (2.7g, 98%). 1H NMR (300 MHz,
CDCl3): δ 7.98 (d, J= 1.8 Hz, 1H), 7.78 (d, J= 6.9 Hz, 2H), 7.65 (dd, J=
7.8 & 1.5 Hz, 1H), 7.59 (d, J= 7.5 Hz, 1H), 7.49 (t, J= 7.5 Hz, 2H), 7.35
(d, J= 8.1 Hz, 2H) and 2.49 (s, 3H) ppm.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Boron-containing small molecules as anti-protozoal agents
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

$DATUM 7732-18-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Representative Procedures Method A: Benzofuran (47.3 mg, 0.40 mmol),
Pd(OAc)2 (9.0 mg, 0.04 mmol), HPMV (71.3 mg, 0.04 mmol), and benzene (3.0
mL) were weighed into a pre-dried pressure vessel inside a glovebox
(Argon). While purging with nitrogen, acetic acid (2.0 mL) was added to
the vessel outside of the glovebox. The flask was then purged three times
with 3 atm of O2 and sealed under pressure. The reaction was stirred at
120 °C for 1.5 hrs. in an oil bath. The resulting mixture was purified by
flash chromatography on silica gel (100% Hexanes). 65.3 mg of a white
solid was produced (84% isolated yield, 98% GC/MS yield). (84% isolated
yield, 98% GC/MS yield)
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM C-C Bond Formation via Double C-H Functionalization: Aerobic Oxidative
Coupling as a Method for Synthesizing Heterocoupled Biaryls
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Dwight, Timothy A.; Rue, Nicholas R.; Charyk, Dagmara; Josselyn, Ryan;
DeBoef, Brenton
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Organic Letters (2007), 9(16), 3137-3139

$DATUM 7732-18-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Compound 3.
9,10-Dihydro-2-methyl-4H-benzo-[5,6]cyclohept[1,2-d]oxazol-4-ol (alcohol
1, 0.2 g, 0.93 mmol) was dissolved in CHCl3 (2 mL) and benzene (1 mL);
CF3SO3H (5 mL, 56 mmol) was then added. The mixture was stirred for 4 h
at room temperature and then poured over ca. 10 g of ice. The resulting
mixture was made basic (pH paper) with dropwise addition of 10 M NaOH and
then extracted twice with CHCl3 (40 mL). The organic extracts were
combined and washed with water and then twice with brine. Following
addition of anhydrous sodium sulfate, filtration, and concentration, it
gives essentially pure (>95%) product 3 (0.25 g, 0.91 mmol, 98%): white
solid, Compound 3, yield (0.25 g, 0.91 mmol, 98%). mp 101-105°C; 1H NMR,
CDCl3, δ: 7.42-7.39 (multiplet, 1H), 7.30- 7.23 (multiplet, 5H),
7.20-7.15 (multiplet, 3H), 5.28 (s, 1H), 2.99-2.92 (multiplet, 2H),
2.79-2.69 (multiplet, 2H), 2.48 (s, 3H). 13C NMR, CDCl3, δ: 158.9, 146.6,
142.9, 142.4, 139.4, 134.9, 130.7, 130.2, 128.1, 127.4, 127.2, 126.8,
126.0, 48.9, 30.4, 26.0, 13.9. Low resolution mass spectra (EI): m/z:
275(M+), 260, 233, 198. HRMS for C19H17NO, calcd 275.1310, found
275.1307.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General method C, for the preparation of
compounds 19 and 26: The trifluoromethyl diketone (1 mmol) is dissolved
in 2 mL C6H6; CF3SO3H (2 mL, 22 mmol) is added slowly with stirring.
After an eight hour reaction at 25°C, the mixture is poured on ice. CHCl3
(ca. 30 mL) is then added and separation of the organic phase is followed
by washings with water, and then twice with saturated brine. The organic
solution is dried with MgSO4, filtered, and concentrated on a rotary
evaporator. The product may then be further purified by recrystallized
from benzene.
2-(1,3-Diphenyl-3-(trifluoromethyl)-2,3-dihydro-1H-inden-1-yl)thiazole
(20): Using general method A, compound 20 was isolated as a yellow
crystals, Yield 98% (Rf 0.4, 2:1 hexanes:ethyl ether): MP 141-145°C
(C6H6). 1H NMR, 500 MHz, CDCl3, δ: 3.51 (d, J= 13.2 Hz, 1H), 4.30 (d, J=
13.2 Hz, 1H), 6.85-6.88 (m, 2H), 6.96-6.98 (m, 3H), 7.02-7.06 (m, 3H),
7.17- 7.19 (m, 2H), 7.29 (d, J= 2.8 Hz, 1H), 7.40-7.41 (m, 1H), 7.49-7.55
(m, 2H), 7.72 (d, J= 7.4 Hz, 1H), 7.82 (d, J= 3.3 Hz, 1H). 13C NMR, 125
MHz, CDCl3, δ: 51.0, 60.2, 60.2 (q, JC-F = 26 Hz), 119.5, 126.8, 126.9,
127.1, 127.3 (q, JC-F = 281 Hz), 127.6, 127.7, 128.1, 128.2, 128.4,
129.0. EIMS: 421 (M+), 352, 249. HRMS clacd for C25H18NF3S 421.11120,
found 421.11131.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM 6-(Dimethylamino)-5-hydroxy-5-phenyl-5,6-dihydropyrrolo[3,4-b]pyridin-7-one
(9a); Typical Procedure To a solution of 6 (0.05 g, 0.26 mmol) in anhyd
benzene (10 mL) was added AlCl3 (0.18 g, 1.31 mmol) and the reaction
mixture was refluxed for 0.5 h. After addition of H2O (10 mL) to the
mixture with ice cooling, the aqueous layer was basified with 10% Na2CO3
(10 mL) and was extracted with EtOAc (2x20 mL). The combined organic
extracts were washed with brine (20 mL), dried (Na2SO4), and
concentrated. The crude product was chromatographed on a silica gel
column (EtOAc) to give 9a. Pale yellow solid, yield (0.69 g, 98%). mp:
142-143°C (EtOAc/hexane). IR (KBr): ν = 3300, 1700, 1660, 1600, 1500
cm-1. 1H NMR (270 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ = 2.73 (s, 6H, 2xCH3), 7.13 (s, 1H,
OH), 7.30-7.41 (m, 5H, ArH), 7.54 (d, 1H, J = 8.1, 4.8 Hz,ArH), 7.64 (dd,
1H, J = 8.1, 1.5 Hz, ArH), 8.75 (dd, 1H, J = 4.8, 1.5 Hz, ArH).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM A new and convenient synthesis of 3-aryl-3-hydroxyisoindol-1-ones and
their aza analogs
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Saito, Yuko; Sakamoto, Takeshi; Kikugawa, Yasuo
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthesis (2001), (2), 221-224

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 126757-08-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for the condensation
reaction of aldehydes/ dicarboxaldehydes with aromatics, using BF3-H2O as
the acid catalyst Aldehydes or dicarboxaldehydes (1mmol) and neat
aromatics (2 mL for liquid aromatics; 4 eqv. for solid aromatics) were
taken in a sealed pressure tube. To this mixture, BF3-H2O (50 eqv., 4.2
g) was added and the mixture was stirred and heated at the required
temperature under closed condition till the reaction is completed.
Completion of the reaction was monitored by TLC and GCMS. The reaction
mixture was then poured into ice-water (10 mL) and extracted with
dichloromethane (3x 20 mL). Combined organic layer was washed with aq.
NaHCO3 solution, then with brine solution, dried over anhydrous Na2SO4
and then solvent was removed under reduced pressure to get the crude
product. The crude product was further purified by column chromatography
over silicagel (65-250 mesh) using hexane-ethyl acetate 2-10% as eluent.
Products were characterized and identified by analyzing their spectral
data (1H, 13C, 19F NMR data, GCMS and HRMS).
1-(Diphenylmethyl)-4-nitrobenzene (7g) 1H NMR δ 5.63 (s, 1H), 7.03-7.09
(m, 4H), 7.22-7.32 (m, 8H), 8.11-8.13 (m, 2H); 13C NMR δ 56.5, 123.5,
126.9, 128.6, 129.2, 129.3, 130.1, 142.2, 151.6; MS (EI), m/z 290.5
(M·+), 164.6 (M·+-Ph-NO2).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM pressure tube used, no solvent
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM BF3-H2O Catalyzed Hydroxyalkylation of Aromatics with Aromatic Aldehydes
and Dicarboxaldehydes: Efficient Synthesis of Triarylmethanes,
Diarylmethylbenzaldehydes, and Anthracene Derivatives
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Prakash, G. K. Surya; Panja, Chiradeep; Shakhmin, Anton; Shah, Eric;
Mathew, Thomas; Olah, George A.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2009), 74(22), 8659-8668

$RFMT $RIREG SCHEME202 STEP1

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure C: Arylation of o-tolyl
dimethylcarbamate (1a) with benzene In a one-dram vial equipped with a
Teflon cap was added o-tolyl dimethylcarbamate (1a) (35.8 mg, 0.2 mmol),
Pd(OAc)2 (4.5 mg, 0.02 mmol, 10 mol%), Pd(OAc)2 (4.5 mg, 0.02 mmol, 10
mol%), Na2S2O8 (142.8 mg, 0.6 mmol), and benzene (1 mL). Subsequently,
trifluoroacetic acid (76 μL, 1 mmol) was added. The vial was sealed with
a Teflon cap and stirred on a heating block at 70 °C for 24 h. A second
portion of Pd(OAc)2 (2.2 mg, 0.01 mmol, 5 mol%) was added and heating was
maintained for an additional 12 h. After cooling to ambient temperature,
the resulting mixture was diluted in 5 mL EtOAc and washed with 5 mL
sat'd NaHCO3. The aqueous phase was extracted with 3 x 10 mL EtOAc. The
combined organic extracts were dried over Na2SO4, concentrated in vacuo
and the resulting residue was purified by preparative thin-layer
chromatography (eluent: hexane/EtOAc = 3:1, v/v) to afford the phenylated
product 2a as a colorless oil (45.8 mg, 90%). 4-Methylbiphenyl-2-yl
dimethylcarbamate (2t): Prepared from 1i according to general procedure C
until a total of 47 h had elapsed (98%). Orange oil. 1H NMR (400 MHz,
CDCl3) δ 7.35-7.27 (m, 4H), 7.24-7.15 (m, 2H), 7.00-6.95 (m, 2H), 2.80
(s, 3H), 2.79 (s, 3H), 2.30 (s, 3H). 13C{1H} NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3) δ
154.8, 148.3, 138.5, 138.0, 131.9, 130.4, 129.1, 128.0, 127.0, 126.5,
123.9, 36.7, 36.3, 21.1. MS (ESI) m/z 256 (M+H), 278 (M+Na); HRMS (ESI)
m/z calc'd for C16H18NO2 [M+H]+: 256.1332; found: 256.1319.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM regioselective, incremental addition of catalyst
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Palladium-Catalyzed Ortho-Arylation of O-Phenylcarbamates with Simple
Arenes and Sodium Persulfate
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Zhao, Xiaodan; Yeung, Charles S.; Dong, Vy M.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of the American Chemical Society (2010), 132(16), 5837-5844

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 98
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 12411-74-4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Catalyst testing. Liquid-phase alkylation of benzene with 1-decene in the
presence of synthesized solid catalyst was carried out at atmospheric
pressure in a 50-mL glass batch reactor equipped with a magnetic
stirrer-heater and condenser. Nano-TiO2-supported Dawson HPA with
different loadings was used as catalyst in the LAB production reaction.
In a typical experimental, supported Dawson catalyst with specified
loading was mixed with benzene and 1-decene and then placed in the glass
reactor. The reaction was conducted at specific constant temperature.
After reaction completion, the mixture was centrifuged to separate
catalyst and then product was identified in the liquid-phase solution and
measured quantitatively using GC-MS. The catalyst was filtered at the end
of the reaction and then washed with water and dried. The dried catalyst
was recycled for the next run under the same conditions. The results
indicated that the activity of the catalyst was not affected even after
the third run with recycled catalyst. This phenomenon implies that there
is no leaching process.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM solid-supported catalyst, nanotitania (n-TiO2)-supported Dawson
heteropolyacid catalyst prepared and used, optimization study, optimized
on stoichiometry of catalyst, optimized on temperature, optimized on
time, optimized on stoichiometry of reactants
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Investigation of linear alkylbenzene synthesis using
nanotitania-supported Dawson heteropolyacid as catalyst by statistical
design approaches
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Toutounchian, Nafiseh; Ahmadpour, Ali; Heravi, Majid M.; Bamoharram,
Fatemeh F.; Ayati, Ali; Deymeh, Fatemeh
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Research on Chemical Intermediates (2016), 42(4), 3283-3301

$DATUM 7732-18-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Reactions of alcohols 1-7, 16: The alcohol (1
mmol) is dissolved in 1mL of C6H6 and 3 mL of CF3SO3H is added. After at
least 2 hrs of stirring, the mixture is poured over ice, and the solution
is made basic with 10 M NaOH. Extraction with CHCl3 is followed by
aqueous washes of H2O (1x) and brine (2x), and then drying with anhydrous
Na2SO4. The product is then purified by chromatography (hexane : EtOAc)
or recrystallization.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM regioselective
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Charge migration in dicationic electrophiles and its application to the
synthesis of aza-polycyclic aromatic compounds

$DATUM Li, Ang; Kindelin, Patrick J.; Klumpp, Douglas A.

$DATUM 92695-50-6
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM I. General Experimental Procedures for Table 1 and Table 2. Pd(OAc)2 (4.5
mg, 0.020 mmol), Cu(OAc)2 (36.2 mg, 0.20 mmol), ligand (0.020 mmol),
n-butyl acrylate (0.030 mL, 0.20 mmol) and arenes (3.0 mL) were added to
a solution tube and the resulting mixture was heated to 120 °C and
stirred for 15 h. After cooling to room temperature, the mixture was
filtrated through a pad of silica gel and washed with ethyl acetate. The
filtrate was concentrated under vacuum, and the residue was purified by
silica gel flash column chromatography. n-butyl cinnamate, yield 97%. 1H
NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.68 (d, J = 16.0 Hz, 1H), 7.55-7.28 (m, 5H),
6.44 (d, J = 16.0 Hz, 1H), 4.21 (t, J = 6.8 Hz, 2H), 1.73-1.64 (m, 2H),
1.51-1.41 (m, 2H), 0.96 (t, J = 7.3 Hz, 3H).

$DATUM 1493-13-6
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Synthetic Procedure: Approximately 0.2
g of the cinnamic acid (ca. 1 mmol) is dissolved in 1 mL arene and 4 mL
of triflic acid is added. The mixture is stirred for 6 hrs and poured
over about 15 g of ice. The resulting mixture is extracted twice with
CHCl3 and the organic extracts are washed with water, then brine, and
dried over MgSO4. Concentration with reduced pressure then gives the
products; if necessary, column chromatography is done over silica.
1-Phenyl-3-(3,4,5-trifluoro-phenyl)-propanone (5m) MP (hexane:ether):
168-170°C; 1H NMR (300 MHz, CHCl3) δ, ppm 7.26 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 2H), 7.43
- 7.50 (m, 1H), 7.53 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 2H), 7.59 - 7.66 (m, 2H), 8.02 (dd,
J = 7.8, 1.5 Hz, 2H); 13C NMR (125 MHz, CHCl3) δ, ppm 112.5 (mult.),
124.1 (mult.), 128.8,129.0,129.8 (mult..), 133.5, 137.8, 141.1 (mult.),
141.5 (mult.), 151.7 (mult.), 189.8; EI MS 262 (M+); HRMS calcd for
Cl5H9OF3, 262.060550, found 262.060992.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM chemoselective
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Superacid-Catalyzed Reactions of Cinnamic Acids and the Role of
Superelectrophiles
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Rendy, Rendy; Zhang, Yun; McElrea, Aaron; Gomez, Alma; Klumpp, Douglas A.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2004), 69(7), 2340-2347

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure:
N-[1-(4-Hydroxyphenyl)-2,2,2-trichloroethyl]-ethoxycarbonylamine (IIIa).
(a) A solution of 0.01 mol of amide I in 10 ml of chloroform, 1 ml of
oleum, and 0.01 mol of phenol were vigorously stirred at room temperature
for 5 h. The reaction mixture was diluted with 15-20 ml of cold water and
with water solution of sodium carbonate. The insoluble reaction product
was filtered off, dried in a vacuum desiccator over P2O5, and
recrystallized from acetone-chloroform mixture, 1: 1. Amides IIIb-d, IVa
were prepared similarly along procedures a.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM oleum used
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Reactions of alcohols 1-7, 16: The alcohol (1
mmol) is dissolved in 1mL of C6H6 and 3 mL of CF3SO3H is added. After at
least 2 hrs of stirring, the mixture is poured over ice, and the solution
is made basic with 10 M NaOH. Extraction with CHCl3 is followed by
aqueous washes of H2O (1x) and brine (2x), and then drying with anhydrous
Na2SO4. The product is then purified by chromatography (hexane : EtOAc)
or recrystallization.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Synthetic Procedure (Products 2, 12,
14, 16, 22, 24, 26, 28): Approximately 0.2 g of the amide (ca. 1 mmol) is
dissolved in 1 mL arene and 4 mL of triflic acid is added. The mixture is
stirred for 6 hrs at 25°C and poured over about 15 g of ice. The
resulting mixture is extracted twice with CHCl3 and the organic extracts
are washed with water, then brine, and dried over MgSO4. Concentration
with reduced pressure then gives the products; if necessary, column
chromatography is done over silica. 14, yield 97%

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Typical Procedure.

acetal (12) (0.37 g, 3.11 mmol) was dissolved in 2.0 mL of benzene, and
3.0 mL of TfOH was slowly added. After 4 h of stirring, the mixture was
poured over ice and neutralized with NaOH. The product was then extracted
into CHCl3 and the organic phase washed with water and then brine, dried
with MgSO4, and concentrated in vacuo. PRODUCT 18g 1H NMR (300 MHz,
CDCl3) δ: 2.27 (s, 6H), 2.90 (d, J = 7.8Hz, 4H), 3.94 (t, J = 7.8Hz, 1H),
7.20-7.40 (m, 10H). 13C NMR (125 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 46.0, 49.7, 65.2, 126.5,
128.3, 128.7, 143.8. Mass Spectrum, (e.i.) m/z: 165, 58
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

Amino Acetals

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM b. 1-Benzyl-4-methyl-4-phenyl piperidine. To a solution of
1-benzyl-4-methyl-4-piperidinol (3.6 g, 17.5 mmol) in 75 mL of benzene
was added AlCl3 (11.7 g, 87.7 mmol) in one portion at room temperature.
After stirring at room temperature for 30 min, the reaction mixture was
heated to reflux for 8 h. The red colored solution was allowed to cool
and then poured over 100 g of ice-water. It was extracted with EtOAc (2 ×
100 mL) and the organic layer was washed with solution of Rochelle's
salt. The organic layer was separated, dried over Na2SO4, filtered and
the solvent was removed in vacuo. It was used in the next step without
further purification. Yield as a red oil (4.5 g, 97% yield).

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7647-01-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 71-43-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7732-18-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Step A 2-(4-Fluoro-phenyl)-1-phenyl-ethanone To a solution of benzene
(182 mL) at 0 °C was added AlCl3 (46.4 g, 348 mmol). A portion of
4-fluorophenyl acetyl chloride (50.0 g, 290 mmol) was then added dropwise
over 30 min. Once the addition was complete, the reaction was allowed to
warm to 25 °C and then heated to 50 °C for 8 hr. Subsequently, the
reaction mixture was cooled to 25 °C and poured onto ice (400 g). To the
resulting suspension in ice was added 1.0 N HCl (50 mL). The organic
layer was separated and washed with 10% HCl, saturated NaHCO3 and brine.
The organic layer was then dried and concentrated to afford a solid that
was washed twice with hexane (200 mL) and then dried under vacuum to
afford 2-(4-fluoro-phenyl)-1-phenyl-ethanone (59.90 g, 97%)
2-(4-Fluoro-phenyl)-1-phenyl-ethanone, yield (59.90 g, 97%) MS(APCI+):
m/z 215.0 (M+H); H-NMR (CDCl3) δ(d, 2 H), 7.54-7.41 (m, 3 H), 7.22-7.17
(m, 2 H), 7.00-6.96 (m, 2 H), 4.23 (s, 3 H).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Preparation of hypocholesterolemic and hypolipidemic N-alkyl pyrroles as
HMGCo-A reductase inhibitors
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Bratton, Larry Don; Miller, Steven Robert; Pfefferkorn, Jeffrey Allen;
Sorenson, Roderick Joseph; Song, Yuntao; Sun, Kuai-Lin; Trivedi, Bharat
Kalidas; Unangst, Paul Charles; Cheng, Xue-Min; Lee, Chitase; Poel,
Toni-Jo
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2005056004 A1 2005-06-23

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Inside a glove box, a 125 mL round-bottom flask equipped with a stirring
bar, reflux condenser, and gas inlet was charged with
4,4'-dichlorobiphenyl-2,2'-disulfonyl dichloride (15.4 g, 36.7 mmoles),
benzene (25 mL, 280 mmoles), and anhydrous nitromethane (75 mL). Aluminum
chloride (11 g, 81 mmoles) was added and the mixture stirred until
dissolved under nitrogen. The solution was heated to 100 °C for 8 hours.
The solution was cooled to room temperature and poured onto 200 g ice
mixed with 100 mL hydrochloric acid. The mixture was extracted several
times with dichloromethane. The organic extracts were washed with water,
dried with sodium carbonate, filtered to give a dark solution. The
solution was treated with decolorizing carbon and heated to a reflux,
then filtered through filter aid, evaporated, and the solids dried at 150
°C in a vacuum oven for 8 hr to give .18.02 g (97 % crude yield). The
mixture was purified by column chromatography using silica gel and
dichloromethane (Rf 0.28) to give 14.3 g (77 % yield) of
2,2'-bis-benzenesulfonyl-4,4'-dichlorobiphenyl. The solids were
recrystallized from xylenes to give 13.08 g (71%).
2,2'-bis-benzenesulfonyl-4,4'-dichlorobiphenyl, yield 18.02 g, 97 % 1H
NMR (DMSO-d6): 6.96 (d, 8.2 Hz, 2H), 7.55 (bs, 4H), 7.56 (m, 8.1 Hz, 4H),
7.69 (m, 2H), 7.74 (dd, 8.2, 2.2 Hz, 2H), 8.13 (d, 2.2 Hz, 2H). 13C NMR
(CDCl3): 128.42 (4 CH), 129.14 (4 CH), 129.58 (2 CH), 132.21 (2 CH),
133.84 (2 CH), 134.13 (2 CH), 134.68 (2 C), 135.61 (2 C), 140.42 (2 C),
141.42 (2 C). MS (M + H+): m/e 502.99 (100 %), 504.99 (75 %), exact mass
for C24H17O4Cl2S2, 502.99 (100 %), 504.99 (72.9 %).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM Friedel-Crafts reaction
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Polyarylene polymers and processes for preparing
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Teasley, Mark F.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2011090705 A2 2011-07-28

$DATUM 1310-73-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7732-18-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Example 21: 4,4-Diphenyl-piperidine 4,4-Diphenyl-piperidine was
synthesized from piperidine-4,4 diol (1.0g, 8.536 mmol), and an excess of
TfOH (10 mL), and benzene (10 mL). The reaction was stirred at room
temperature for 4 hours. The reaction was poured onto ice. The solution
was made basic using 1M NaOH and then extracted with dichloromethane. The
organic layer was washed with water and then brine. The organic layer was
dried over Na2SO4 filtered and concentrated to give a white solid (1.49g,
96.8%). 4,4-Diphenyl-piperidine, yield 1.49g, 96.8%. 1H NMR (300MHZ,
CDCl3): (ppm) 2.664 (t, 4H, 2(C-CH2-C)) 3.219 (t, 4H, 2(N-CH2-C),
7.200-7.384 (m, 10H, H-Ar).

$DATUM 5,6,7,8-Tetrahydro-6,8-diphenyl-3(2H)-isoquinolinone (30). Method a. To a
solution of AlBr3 (1.2 g, 4.5 mmol) inbenzene (3 mL) was added 12 (0.145
g, 1 mmol). The resulting solution was stirred at 25°C for 4 h, then
poured over ice and extracted with CH2Cl2. The organic phase was washed
with water and aqueous NaHCO3, dried (MgSO4), and concentrated to provide
crystalline product 30 (0.292 g, 97%) as a mixture of cis-trans isomers
(∼3:1). HRMS: C21H19NO calcd 301.1467, found 301.1470. Recrystallization
of the mixture from acetone gave cis-30 (0.15 g, 50%): mp 258-260°C; 1H
NMR (CDCl3) δ 2.03 (q, J 12.4 Hz, 1H), 2.25-2.35 (m, 1H), 2.85-3.2 (m,
3H), 3.95 (dd, J 12.4, 4.5 Hz, 1H), 6.31 (s, 1H), 6.81 (s, 1H), 7.2- 7.4
(m, 10H); 13C NMR (CDCl3) δ 38.5, 40.4, 40.5, 44.7, 116.8, 121.1, 126.6,
126.8, 127.1, 128.4, 128.7, 128.9, 134.6, 144.4, 144.9, 153.8, 164.1.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Aryl 5-arylisoxazol-3-yl ketones XI-XIV
(general procedure). A mixture of 10 mmol of acid chloride XV or XVI, 12
mmol of anhydrous AlCl3, and 200 mmol of anhydrous benzene or toluene was
stirred for 30 min at 20°C and for 3 h at 80°C. The mixture was then
diluted with 100 ml of chloroform, treated with 10 ml of water,
thoroughly stirred, and poured into water acidified to pH 3-4. The
organic phase was separated, washed with water, a dilute solution of
potassium carbonate, and water again, and dried over calcium chloride.
The solvent was distilled off under reduced pressure, and the solid
residue was recrystallized from chloroform-hexane (1 : 2).
Phenyl(5-phenyl-1,2-oxazol-3-yl)methanone (XI). Yield 97%. mp 86-87°C. IR
spectrum, ν, cm-1: 1655 (C═O), 1610, 1597, 1579, 1571, 1493, 1449, 1441,
1426 (C═C, C═N). 1H NMR spectrum, δ, ppm: 7.06 s (1H, 4-H), 7.49 m (3H,
Harom), 7.54 d.d (2H, Harom, 3J = 7.6 Hz), 7.66 d.d (1H, Harom, 3J = 7.6
Hz), 7.85 d (2H, Harom, 3J = 7.6 Hz), 8.35 d (2H, Harom, 3J = 7.6 Hz).
13C NMR spectrum, δC, ppm: 100.40 (C4), 126.14 (2C, CHarom), 128.74 (2C,
CHarom), 129.30 (2C, CHarom), 130.85 (2C, CHarom), 130.88 (CHarom),
134.21 (CHarom); 126.85, 135.88, 162.57, 170.92 (Cquat); 185.94 (C═O).
Found, %: C 77.21; H 4.32; N 5.65. m/z 249 [M]+. C16H11NO2. Calculated,
%: C 77.10; H 4.45; N 5.62. M 249.28.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM Friedel-Crafts acylation

$DATUM Synthesis of Ir(NC)(NNtBu)(C6H5)OTf (8a). In a Schlenk bomb complex 7a
(100 mg, 0.12 mmol) was heated at 170 °C in benzene (30 mL) for 6.5 h.
The solvent was then removed under reduced pressure. The resulting yellow
microcrystalline solid was redissolved in a minimal amount of CH2Cl2 and
reprecipitated with pentane, yielding 103.9 mg (96.9%) of 8a. Anal. Calcd
for 8a: C, 53.64; H, 4.39; N, 6.10,; F, 6.21. Found: C, 53.30; H, 4.31;
N, 6.03; F 6.33. 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 9.18 (d, 1H, 3 J = 5.9, H-1), 8.89 (d,
1H, 3 J = 6.1, NNtBu), 8.40 (d, 1H, 3 J = 8.1, H-4), 8.13 (d, 1H, 4 J =4
J = 2.0, NNtBu), 8.07 (d, 1H, 4 J = 1.8, NNtBu), 8.04 (d, 2H, 3 J = 7.3,
H-12), 7.82(dt, 1H, 3 J = 7.8, 4 J = 1.4, H-3), 7.61 (d, 1H, 3 J = 5.9,
NNtBu), 7.46-7.32(m, 5H, H-2, 13, 14, NNtBu), 7.27(dd, 1H, 3 J = 5.9, 4 J
= 1.8, NNtBu), 7.17 (d, 1H, 3 J = 8.2, H-8), 7.11-6.60(bs, Ph), 6.86(bt,
1H, 3 J = 7.0, Ph), 6.53(d, 1H, 3 J = 8.1, H-9), 1.50(s, 9H, CMe3),
1.35(s, 9H, CMe3). 13C{1H} NMR (CDCl3): δ 161.17, 162.55, 161.90, 159.06,
156.14, 152.80, 149.82, 149.08, 148.17, 139.41, 138.97, 137.60, 137.51,
135.45, 128.64, 128.28, 128.03, 126.45, 125.72, 124.56, 124.25, 124.18,
122.39, 121.14, 120.86(q, CF3, J = 318.6), 120.66, 119.31, 118.88,
35.43(CMe3), 35.36(CMe3), 30.38(CMe 3), 30.26(CMe 3). 19F NMR (CDCl3): δ
-78.97.
